name: The First People's Spirits
description: The San — also called Bushmen, though many groups reject that colonial term — are among the oldest continuous cultures on Earth, with genetic and archaeological evidence placing their lineage in southern Africa for at least 100,000 years. Tsodilo Hills in northwestern Botswana, four quartzite inselbergs rising from the Kalahari sandveld, holds over 4,500 rock paintings spanning tens of thousands of years — the densest concentration of rock art in the world, called by the local San 'the Mountains of the Gods.' The spiritual practices documented here are not a single unified religion but a family of related traditions across many distinct groups — the Ju/'hoansi of the Nyae Nyae area, the /Xam of the South African Cape (whose voices survive in the 12,000 pages of the Bleek and Lloyd archive), the Naro, the G/wi, the Hai//om, and dozens of others. What connects them is not a shared pantheon but a shared mode of knowing: the trance dance, in which healers enter altered states of consciousness to access the spirit world and heal the sick. Rock art evidence suggests this practice extends back at least 27,000 years and possibly much further. The oldest identifiable religious act on Earth is not worship, not sacrifice, not prayer. It is healing.

deities.name: /Kaggen
deities.title: The Trickster-Creator (Mantis)
deities.description: /Kaggen — the Mantis — is the central supernatural figure of /Xam San tradition, and he may be the most complex trickster in any mythology on Earth. He is not a god in the hierarchical sense. He is a shape-shifter, a creator, a fool, a mourner, a resurrector. He takes the form of a praying mantis, but also an eland, a snake, a louse, a hartebeest. In the /Xam narratives recorded by Wilhelm Bleek and Lucy Lloyd between 1870 and 1884 — working directly with /Xam speakers including //Kabbo, /Han≠kass'o, and Dia!kwain, who dictated their traditions in their own language — /Kaggen creates the eland, the most sacred animal in San cosmology, by nurturing it in secret with honey. When his sons discover and kill the eland, /Kaggen weeps. He creates, and the creation is destroyed, and he grieves, and then he creates again. This is not a triumphant creator myth. It is a creation story built on loss and renewal, which is psychologically closer to how creation actually works than any narrative of omnipotent design. /Kaggen is also ridiculous. He gets stuck in things. He misunderstands situations. He makes terrible decisions. He is humiliated and then recovers through cunning or luck. Roger Hewitt's 1986 analysis of the Bleek and Lloyd texts showed that /Kaggen stories function simultaneously as entertainment, moral instruction, and cosmological framework — they are funny and profound at the same time, which is a combination most Western theology cannot manage. The praying mantis itself, with its patient stillness followed by explosive action, its strange alien beauty, its predatory precision disguised as prayer, is an animal that already looks like a paradox. The San chose well.

deities.name: //Gauwa
deities.title: The Supreme Being
deities.description: //Gauwa (also //Gãuwa, Gaoxa) is the great god of the Ju/'hoansi San, documented most thoroughly by Lorna Marshall during her family's expeditions to the Nyae Nyae area of Namibia in the 1950s and expanded by Megan Biesele's decades of fieldwork. //Gauwa is deeply ambivalent — not good, not evil, but both, depending on his mood and the circumstances. He created the world and the people in it, but he also sends sickness and death. The Ju/'hoansi do not worship him in the Western sense; their relationship to //Gauwa is more like negotiation, complaint, and sometimes open argument. Healers in the trance dance confront //Gauwa's spirits (the //gauwasi, the spirits of the dead, who serve as his agents) and argue with them, demanding that they release the sick person. This is not submission to the divine — it is contestation. Richard Katz, in his 1982 study 'Boiling Energy,' documented how Ju/'hoansi healers described shouting at //Gauwa, bargaining with him, telling him he could not have this person yet. The psychological framework here is radically different from most world religions: the supreme being is not to be obeyed but engaged, and the engagement can be adversarial. //Gauwa lives in the eastern sky, where the sun rises, and the spirits of the dead travel to him. But he also walks the earth at night. He leaves footprints. He is enormous and dangerous, but the healers, when they are filled with n/um (the boiling healing energy activated in trance), can face him. This produces a theology where human courage is not a gift from God but a tool used against God — or at least against his darker intentions.

deities.name: !Xu
deities.title: The Great God
deities.description: !Xu (also ≠Gao!na, ≠Gao N!a) is the great god of the Ju/'hoansi in some tellings — the same tradition, different name, different emphasis, depending on the storyteller and the region. Where //Gauwa emphasizes the ambivalent, dangerous aspects of the supreme being, !Xu carries more of the creative, benevolent associations. Megan Biesele's 'Women Like Meat' (1993), based on decades of work with Ju/'hoansi narrators, documented stories in which !Xu created the world and gave people their tools, their fire, their knowledge of plants and animals. But !Xu is also a trickster — he plays tricks on people, he can be foolish, he makes mistakes. The overlap with /Kaggen is real and important: San supreme beings do not separate the creator from the fool. They are the same figure. This is not theological confusion; it is theological honesty. Creation is not clean work, and the being who does it is not above making a mess of things. The /Xam and Ju/'hoansi traditions developed independently over thousands of years in different ecological zones — the /Xam in the semi-arid Karoo of the Cape, the Ju/'hoansi in the Kalahari sandveld — yet both arrived at the same structural insight: the highest power is also the most unpredictable. Mathias Guenther's comparative work on San religion emphasizes that these are not fixed doctrines but living, flexible narrative traditions, shaped by individual storytellers, adapted to local conditions, and comfortable with contradiction in ways that literate, scripture-based religions are not.

deities.name: /Xam Moon
deities.title: The Moon Who Dies and Returns
deities.description: The Moon in /Xam tradition is not a passive celestial object but a being who dies and is reborn each month — a figure whose story is among the most poignant in the Bleek and Lloyd archive. The Moon was once full and round, and he angered the Sun, who took a knife and cut away pieces of him, slicing him thinner and thinner until only a spine remained — the thin crescent visible before the new moon. But the Moon does not stay dead. He returns, growing back from that spine, filling himself out again over the nights, until he is whole. Then the Sun cuts him again. This cycle — destruction, near-death, return, fullness, destruction again — is the oldest astronomical observation embedded in narrative that we have from any human culture, and the /Xam version carries a specific emotional charge: the Moon asked the Hare to carry a message to human beings, telling them that as the Moon dies and returns, so too would people die and return. But the Hare garbled the message, telling people that they would die and not return. The Moon struck the Hare in fury, splitting his lip (which is why hares have cleft lips), but the damage was done. Human mortality, in this telling, is a communication error — not a divine punishment, not a consequence of sin, but a botched message. The psychological weight of this is considerable: death is not supposed to be permanent. It is an accident of transmission. The /Xam looked at the Moon every night and saw the proof of what should have been theirs.

deities.name: Eland Spirit
deities.title: The Most Sacred Animal
deities.description: The eland — the largest African antelope, Taurotragus oryx — occupies a position in San spirituality that has no precise parallel in other traditions. It is not a god, not a totem, not a symbol. It is the animal closest to the divine, the creature most saturated with n/um (spiritual potency), and its presence runs through every layer of San life: birth, puberty, marriage, death, healing, and the trance dance itself. David Lewis-Williams, in 'Believing and Seeing' (1981) and subsequent work, demonstrated that the dying eland is the central image in San rock art — depicted with lowered head, crossed legs, and hair standing on end, the same physical signs that a real eland displays in death and that a human healer displays when entering deep trance. The parallel is deliberate. When a healer enters trance, he or she is 'dying' like the eland, crossing into the spirit world, and the potency released in that crossing is the same potency that the eland carries in its blood and fat. /Kaggen created the first eland from honey and shoe leather, nurtured it in secret, loved it. The /Xam girl's puberty ceremony (the Eland Bull Dance) involves women dancing in imitation of eland cows while a man plays the eland bull, and the girl is anointed with eland fat. At Tsodilo Hills, eland paintings dominate the rock panels — painted in the characteristic bent-forward posture of trance death, in red and white pigments mixed with eland blood and fat. The paint itself contains the animal's potency. The image is not a representation of the eland. It is the eland's power, fixed to the rock surface, still active.

deities.name: Rain Bull
deities.title: The Bringer of Rain
deities.description: The Rain Animal — sometimes a bull, sometimes a snake, sometimes a fantastical creature with features of several animals — is one of the most important figures in /Xam San tradition, and its capture and killing is described in the Bleek and Lloyd archive as one of the primary tasks of the rain-maker, a specialist shaman who could enter trance, travel to the waterhole where the Rain Animal lived, and lead it across the land so that where it walked, or where its blood and milk fell, rain would come. The Rain Bull is male rain — a hard, driving, sometimes destructive downpour. The Rain Cow is female rain — gentle, soaking, the rain that makes things grow. /Xam narrators described the Rain Animal as beautiful and dangerous, with specific colors and forms that varied by storyteller. The rain-maker had to capture it with special techniques — sometimes a leather thong, sometimes by scent, sometimes by stealth — and lead it across the parched land, then cut its throat so that its blood became rain. The rock art at sites across southern Africa depicts these rain animals: strange, composite creatures that do not match any real animal, painted in the posture of being led on a thong. Lewis-Williams identified these images as depictions of trance experience — the rain-maker seeing the Rain Animal in the spirit world and interacting with it there, then recording the encounter on stone. In the Kalahari, where drought is the permanent background condition and rain is the event that makes life possible, the Rain Animal is not a quaint folk belief. It is the spiritual technology for the most urgent practical problem: water.

deities.name: Star People
deities.title: The Ancestors in the Sky
deities.description: In /Xam tradition, as recorded by Bleek and Lloyd, the stars are people of the Early Race — beings who lived before the present order, when animals and people were not yet fully distinct, and who were transformed into celestial objects at the beginning of the current world. The Milky Way is wood ashes thrown into the sky by a girl of the Early Race so that people could see the path at night — the !kumm, the 'backbone of the night.' The stars that make up what Europeans call the Southern Cross and the Pointers are male figures — specifically, the Pointers are lions, and the Southern Cross stars are other beings in a hunting narrative fixed permanently in the sky. The Pleiades are women, and their rising marks seasons. This is not decorative storytelling. /Xam astronomical knowledge was precise and practical — star positions marked seasons for hunting, gathering, and the movement of game. But the framework is also existential: the sky is full of former people. Every night, the /Xam looked up and saw their ancestors. The transformation from human to star is not death but a change of state — the Early Race people are still there, still visible, still arranged in the relationships they had when they lived on the ground. Janette Deacon and Thomas Dowson's work on /Xam star lore showed that these narratives encode observational astronomy of considerable sophistication, embedded in stories that children could memorize and enjoy. The Kalahari, with its flat horizons and minimal light pollution, offers one of the most spectacular night skies on Earth. At Tsodilo Hills, the quartzite surfaces catch starlight, and the paintings on the rock faces exist in dialogue with the sky above them.

deities.name: N/um
deities.title: The Boiling Healing Energy
deities.description: N/um (also num, n|um — the spelling varies across orthographies) is not a deity but a spiritual force, and it may be the most important concept in San religion. It is the energy that resides in the pit of the stomach and, when activated through the rhythmic exertion of the trance dance, rises up the spine and 'boils' — the Ju/'hoansi word is kia, the moment when the healer's n/um boils over and he or she enters the spirit world. Richard Katz's fieldwork documented the experience in the healers' own words: the stomach heats up, the spine burns, the legs tremble, the healer may scream, cry, collapse, bleed from the nose. The other dancers — typically women clapping and singing the medicine songs, which are themselves vehicles for n/um — maintain the rhythm that sustains the healer's trance. The healer then 'sees' the sickness in the patient's body, pulls it out with the hands, and shrieks it away into the darkness, expelling it. This is not performance. Brain imaging studies of comparable trance states show measurable neurological changes. The San trance dance is the oldest known form of healing ritual, with rock art evidence at sites including Tsodilo Hills and across the Drakensberg showing the characteristic postures — arms back, torso bent forward, nasal bleeding — in paintings dated to at least 27,000 years ago. What is psychologically arresting is the communal structure: n/um is activated by the community's singing and clapping, but it flows through the individual healer. The healer cannot boil n/um alone. Healing requires a group. The oldest spiritual practice on Earth is not solitary meditation or individual prayer. It is a community holding the rhythm while one person crosses over to fight for another's life.

deities.name: Therianthropy
deities.title: Human-Animal Transformation
deities.description: Therianthropes — beings that are part human, part animal — are among the most striking and widespread images in San rock art, from the Drakensberg to Tsodilo Hills to the Brandberg in Namibia. They are not mythological creatures in the sense that a griffin or a centaur is mythological. They are records of trance experience. Lewis-Williams and Dowson's neuropsychological model, published in 1988, argued that in deep trance states, the human nervous system produces predictable hallucinations — entoptic patterns (grids, spirals, zigzags) in the early stages, and full therianthropic visions in the deepest stage, where the healer experiences transformation into an animal. The San healer does not believe he is turning into an eland or a lion. He experiences it. His body changes. His senses shift. He sees from the animal's perspective. And when he comes out of trance, he paints what he experienced: a figure with a human body and an eland's head, or a human with antelope hooves, or a being caught mid-transformation, the limbs ambiguous between species. These images are not decorative and they are not imaginary. They are phenomenologically accurate records of what altered states of consciousness look like from the inside. The Tsodilo Hills paintings include therianthropic figures that may be among the oldest such images in the world. The concept challenges the Western boundary between 'human' and 'animal' at its root — in the San framework, that boundary is crossable, and crossing it is not regression or madness but a spiritual skill. The healer who can become the eland can access its n/um. The boundary is a door, and the trance dance is the key.

deities.name: Dassie
deities.title: /Kaggen's Wife — The Rock Hyrax
deities.description: In /Xam tradition, /Kaggen has a family, and they are as important to the narrative cycle as he is. His wife is the Dassie (rock hyrax, Procavia capensis) — called /Huntu!katt!katten in /Xam — a small, unassuming mammal that lives in rocky outcrops across southern Africa and is, improbably, the closest living relative of the elephant. /Kaggen's family includes his son-in-law Kwammang-a, his daughter the Porcupine, and his grandson the Ichneumon (a mongoose), who serves as /Kaggen's critic — the voice of reason who tells the trickster-creator that his plans are foolish, and who is almost always right. The domestic structure of /Kaggen's household grounds the cosmic trickster in the mundane: he has in-law problems, he argues with his grandson, his wife is more sensible than he is. This is not a diminishment of the divine — it is a refusal to separate the divine from the ordinary. The Bleek and Lloyd archive shows /Kaggen as a being whose cosmic actions (creating the eland, placing the Moon in the sky, giving the sun its heat) emerge from the same narrative fabric as his domestic squabbles and embarrassments. The Dassie, as his wife, is the anchor that keeps the trickster from spinning entirely out of control. She is practical where he is visionary, patient where he is impulsive, and her small, rock-dwelling nature — hidden, watchful, warm-blooded in the cold stone — mirrors the quiet persistence that holds any household, or any cosmos, together while the more dramatic personalities take the credit.
